00023 int lies_above_points(const double a, const data_point *points, const int num_data_points) {
00024     double y = 0, y_hat = 0;
00025     int i;
00026     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00027     {
00028         if (   (points[i].y == 0) || (points[i].y == 1)
00029             || (points[i].x == 0) || (points[i].x == 1))
00030         {
00031             y_hat = points[i].y;     /* the actual value    */
00032             y = pow(points[i].x, a); /* the estimated value */
00033         }
00034         else
00035         {
00036             y_hat = log(points[i].y); /* the actual value:    log(y)              */
00037             y = (a)*log(points[i].x); /* the estimated value: log(x^a) = a.log(x) */
00038         }
00039 
00040         if (y < y_hat)
00041             return 0;
00042     }
00043     return 1;
00044 }

00056 int lies_below_points(const double a, const data_point *points, const int num_data_points) {
00057     double y = 0, y_hat = 0;
00058     int i;
00059     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00060     {
00061         if (   (points[i].y == 0) || (points[i].y == 1)
00062             || (points[i].x == 0) || (points[i].x == 1))
00063         {
00064             y_hat = points[i].y;     /* the actual value    */
00065             y = pow(points[i].x, a); /* the estimated value */
00066         }
00067         else
00068         {
00069             y_hat = log(points[i].y); /* the actual value:    log(y)              */
00070             y = (a)*log(points[i].x); /* the estimated value: log(x^a) = a.log(x) */
00071         }
00072 
00073         if (y > y_hat)
00074             return 0;
00075     }
00076     return 1;
00077 }
00078 
00087 double initial_function(data_point *points, int num_data_points) {
00088     double a = 5;
00089 
00090     /* If the value of a is not large enough to make the function x^a
00091        lie above all the data points, then double it and try again    */
00092     while (!lies_above_points(a, points, num_data_points)) {
00093         a = 2*a;
00094     }
00095     return a;
00096 }

00109 int compare_data_points(const void *struct1, const void *struct2)
00110 {
00111     data_point *dp1 = (data_point *)struct1, *dp2 = (data_point *)struct2;
00112     if (dp1->x < dp2->x)
00113         return -1;
00114     else if (dp1->x > dp2->x)
00115         return 1;
00116     else
00117         return 0;
00118 }

00121 void find_upper_bound(double func[5], const data_point *points, const int num_data_points)
00122 {
00123     /* You're wasting your time using this method when you have less than 2 points. This
00124        method will give you a meainingful result if there are more than 3 data points.   */
00125     if (num_data_points < 2)
00126     {
00127         func[0] = 1;
00128         func[1] = points[0].x;
00129         func[2] = points[0].y;
00130         func[3] = points[1].y - func[1];
00131         func[4] = points[1].x - func[2];
00132         return;
00133     }
00134 
00135     /* Check that we have unique x coordinates (ie. we have a mathematical function).
00136        This algorithm won't work otherwise.                                           */
00137     data_point *_points = (data_point *)malloc(sizeof(data_point)*num_data_points);
00138     int i;
00139     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00140     {
00141         _points[i].x = points[i].x;
00142         _points[i].y = points[i].y;
00143     }
00144     qsort(_points, num_data_points, sizeof(data_point), &compare_data_points);
00145     for (i = 1; i < num_data_points; i++)
00146     {
00147         if (_points[i].x == _points[i-1].x) /* We don't have a mathematical function. */
00148         {
00149             func[0] = 0;
00150             func[1] = points[0].x;
00151             func[2] = points[0].y;
00152             func[3] = points[1].y - func[1];
00153             func[4] = points[1].x - func[2];
00154             return;
00155         }
00156     }
00157 
00158     /* Shift the points towards the origin. */
00159     func[1] = _points[0].x;
00160     func[2] = _points[0].y;
00161 
00162     /* Scale the points to a polynomial of the form y = x^a (so that there is only one
00163        constant we have to worry about - i.e. the 'a').                                */
00164     func[3] = _points[1].x - func[1];
00165     if (func[3] == 0) func[3] = 1;
00166 
00167     func[4] = _points[1].y - func[2];
00168     if (func[4] == 0) func[4] = 1;
00169 
00170     /* Now perform the actual shift and scaling. */
00171     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00172     {
00173         _points[i].x = (_points[i].x - func[1])/func[3];
00174         _points[i].y = (_points[i].y - func[2])/func[4];
00175     }
00176 
00177     /* We are trying to find a polynomial of the form x^a */
00178     double ahigh, alow, atemp, error;
00179 
00180     /* Get an initial function */
00181     ahigh = initial_function(_points, num_data_points);
00182     alow = 0;
00183 
00184     do {
00185         /* Use the `divide & conquer' approach to find a good upper bound estimate. */
00186         atemp = (ahigh + alow)/2;
00187         if (lies_above_points(atemp, _points, num_data_points))
00188             ahigh = atemp;
00189         else
00190             alow = atemp;
00191         error = ahigh - alow;
00192     }while (error > 0.0005);
00193 
00194     func[0] = ahigh;
00195     free(_points);
00196 }

00199 void find_lower_bound(double func[5], const data_point *points, const int num_data_points)
00200 {
00201     /* You're wasting your time using this method when you have less than 2 points. This
00202        method will give you a meainingful result if there are more than 3 data points.   */
00203     if (num_data_points < 2)
00204     {
00205         func[0] = 1;
00206         func[1] = points[0].x;
00207         func[2] = points[0].y;
00208         func[3] = points[1].y - func[1];
00209         func[4] = points[1].x - func[2];
00210         return;
00211     }
00212 
00213     /* Check that we have unique x coordinates (ie. we have a mathematical function).
00214        This algorithm won't work otherwise.                                           */
00215     data_point *_points = (data_point *)malloc(sizeof(data_point)*num_data_points);
00216     int i;
00217     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00218     {
00219         _points[i].x = points[i].x;
00220         _points[i].y = points[i].y;
00221     }
00222     qsort(_points, num_data_points, sizeof(data_point), &compare_data_points);
00223     for (i = 1; i < num_data_points; i++)
00224     {
00225         if (_points[i].x == _points[i-1].x) /* We don't have a mathematical function. */
00226         {
00227             func[0] = 0;
00228             func[1] = points[0].x;
00229             func[2] = points[0].y;
00230             func[3] = points[1].y - func[1];
00231             func[4] = points[1].x - func[2];
00232             return;
00233         }
00234     }
00235 
00236     /* Shift the points towards the origin. */
00237     func[1] = _points[0].x;
00238     func[2] = _points[0].y;
00239 
00240     /* Scale the points to a polynomial of the form y = x^a (so that there is only one
00241        constant we have to worry about - i.e. the 'a').                                */
00242     func[3] = _points[1].x - func[1];
00243     if (func[3] == 0) func[3] = 1;
00244 
00245     func[4] = _points[1].y - func[2];
00246     if (func[4] == 0) func[4] = 1;
00247 
00248     /* Now perform the actual shift and scaling. */
00249     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00250     {
00251         _points[i].x = (_points[i].x - func[1])/func[3];
00252         _points[i].y = (_points[i].y - func[2])/func[4];
00253     }
00254 
00255     /* We are trying to find a polynomial of the form x^a */
00256     double ahigh, alow, atemp, error;
00257 
00258     /* Get an initial function */
00259     ahigh = initial_function(_points, num_data_points);
00260     alow = 0;
00261 
00262     do {
00263         /* Use the `divide & conquer' approach to find a good upper bound estimate. */
00264         atemp = (ahigh + alow)/2;
00265         if (lies_below_points(atemp, _points, num_data_points))
00266             alow = atemp;
00267         else
00268             ahigh = atemp;
00269         error = ahigh - alow;
00270     }while (error > 0.0005);
00271 
00272     func[0] = alow;
00273     free(_points);
00274 }

00276 
00277 double sum_error(double ub[5], const data_point *points, const int num_data_points)
00278 {
00279     double error = 0;
00280     int i;
00281     for (i = 0; i < num_data_points; i++)
00282     {
00283         error = error + pow((points[i].x - ub[1])/ub[3], ub[0])*ub[4] + ub[2] - points[i].y;
00284     }
00285     return error;
00286 }
